review_title: Well-meaning people and managers who lack collaborative leadership skills
pros: Staff and management have the best interests of the clients at heart and are committed to supporting and helping them improve their lives. The programs provide good exposure to the field of human services for those entering the field.
cons: The top-down management style creates a low-trust work environment, characterized by favoritism and exclusion. The same people continued to have visibility and recognition, resulting in a work culture that is not open to new voices or ideas. As a middle manager, my senior manager was stretched so thin they could not answer emails in a timely way and often did not show up for regularly scheduled meetings. This affected my ability to get approvals and run my program effectively as I lacked autonomy for decision-making. For someone with over 20 years of experience as a manager, used to working collaboratively, I felt disempowered and dismissed.

pros: The people you work with are cool, and so is helping clients
cons: Upper management does not have it together. Pay is terrible even by nonprofit standards, and problems remain unsolved.

pros: -accredited organization - able to move programs easily
cons: - sometimes disorganized - challenges are many - almost too big of an organization. They do a lots of things ok but very few well

cons: Working hours are late, Benefits are not the best. Pay is not the most competitive.

job_title: Crisis Intervention Specialist in Denville, NJ
pros: You will gain experience within the field. They offer internship opportunities and hold flexible scheduling. They will provide appropriate training but those can be taken away if work is needed to be done. This will prepare you for working within the community since you are going to the individuals house.
cons: Very hard work for no added bonuses. You will work over your shift at times for no compensation. This job is hard to sustain due to the stress level and immediacy of the job. You will learn and gain insight within the mental health field, but the burn out rate is high and a high turn-over. Most people usually stay within 2 years in this position. You are not compensated appropriately for the amount of work. You will have to work one/two holidays a year due to on-call shifts. This program is 24/7 which is great for families but if you're on-call, you never know what the day will hold. This is a bachelor's level position so you will be compensated at that level. You can grow within the position but it is limited due to it being a bachelor's level position. Master's are welcomed. I have had many sleepless nights due to burnout and working with high risk families with limited support after difficult dispatches.

review_title: It's  all about that almight buck!
job_title: Family Services Worker in Altoona, PA
pros: You can make a extreme amount of money if your will to put in the hours!
cons: Its a unspoken expectation that you work where and when they want you to. All hell breaks out if you try to refuse a job or ask for a day off, no matter how tired you are. I Needed to take a emergency leave of absence , it was a matter of life and death! I was fired when I did not go back to my position by the estimated date or return. It's sad the number of staff the clients go through because they are worked so hard.

pros: I am working with amazing people within my office. The company itself has embraced the social injustice and made efforts to dismantle the systematic racism by providing training and support groups. We will no longer be off on Columbus Day but will be on Juneteenth. The company's safety precautions during COVID-19.
cons: The company itself may be VERY different from my experience within my program. There is favoritism in the program, and higher-ups are responsible for it. Once they have obtained what they want from sweat and hard work, they treat you as worthless. The micromanagement is exhausting which is instructed by the Director, which makes the workers feel undervalued. There is a high overturn because of management people don't leave a good job they leave bad management.

pros: This company used to be great and they used to do great work. I started off at one of the group homes several years ago. My supervisor was great, the staff was well trained and ran like a well-oiled machine. The kids were challenging but it felt like we were making a positive change in their lives.
cons:
It seems like the Residential leadership plays favorites, the leadership is not at all representative of the majority of the staff and the clients. The residential programs are a disorganized mess. We are failing these kids and it's sad. They seem to hire anyone with a pulse to take care of these kids, but what can you expect for poverty wages? The staff turnover is very high. 

The executives pay themselves insanely high salaries + bonuses, at the expense of paying the rest of the staff minimum wage.

review_title: Great place to work....pay NOT the best...
pros: Very caring about your family.  This agency cares about the personal needs of its employees.  If you have a sick child, you are not left to feel guilty for taking off.  Management cares about your personal well being.
cons: The work load increases and the pay does not.  Employees are expected to go above and beyond and we are not compensated for our efforts.  Raises have not been given in over 4 years, but the workload increases. Many of the resources needed to complete our job is limited.  You are expected to perform at a certain level, but there are so many things (computers, etc.) preventing you from delivering services at your best.  Human Resources is horrible!

pros: Good values, nice people, nice to feel that my work made a difference, holidays
cons: Really low salaries/raises, no bonuses

review_title: Great agency who provides a variety of services to the Camden County and Beyond.
pros: The agency has Flexible work hours, there is room for upwards movement and good communication with administration. The agency has strong ties in the community and can be very affective in advocating for families.
cons: The pay does not reflect the education nor the work the staff does. The work is rewarding spiritually, but the pay does not  reflect the increase in housing cost as well as student loan payments. We risk our lives everyday entering homes to help others in need obtain resources they need such as shelter and food and at times we ourselves are lacking in basic needs. It's hard to advocate for higher education when you are in line with your clients at the board of social services seeking support.

pros: provide services for children on a whole
cons: Specifically, the YES program is more interested in the money coming in per client then the service rendered.  Proper staff ratio of 1 to 5 clients is often compromised especially overnight/3rd shift duty. Clients do not receive adequate discipline for their behavior even when it is criminal. The clients act like it is the YES, WE CAN Program where they are free to be mutinous!

review_title: Rewarding, but terrible benefits and pay
pros: Personally rewarding work, generous time off
cons: Horrendous benefits that they make you pay way too much for (employee & spouse is more than half my check every single pay period and doctors laugh at me when they see how terrible the plan is), pay is low even for a nonprofit, lots of favoritism

review_title: Too much growth without good infrastructure
pros: Diminishing. Work independently good interactions w clients qualified staff dedicated staff
cons: New management structure created a new level of middlemen that is inefficient. The new management talks only to itself and creates policies without considering practical implementation or impact on how programs operate. No pay raise in 8 years! Micromanaging staff on small matters. Workloads are overwhelming and cannot be accomplished in a work week. Have to take work home or work on weekends on a regular basis.

pros: Opportunity to have a positive effect on people, rewarding work, ability to transfer, paid travel
cons: Little to no administrative support (depending on branch), insufficient pay, excessive work hours, unorganized,  no transparency with budgets, lack of  effective communication

pros: Center For Family Services does an amazing job of creating a culture that is centered around treating employees like family. Leadership sets this culture in motion and it is disseminated throughout each of the organization's programs. The organization is lead by true leaders who are forward thinking change makers with the good of the community in mind every step of the way. With the organization growing quickly there are opportunities for advancement.
cons: A more structured and consistent management training would be incredibly helpful for both new and more experienced supervisors.

pros: When a program loses funding, the company's leads do as much as they can to find  a replacement position for the employees they find value in.
cons: G and A staff such as HR, Operations, etc receive their salaries from funding from programming. This can cause programs to suffer due to lack of staff. Staffers are wearing numerous hats; many are overworked, stressed- out, and resentful. G and A staffers have received raises when program staff did not.

pros: Center For Family Services offers an opportunity to be part of a team working toward a common goal of changing the lives of people in need.
cons: Making a positive impact on the lives of children and families who have faced overwhelming challenges brings it's own set of stressors and challenges. Self care  is an important part of maintaining the positive energy needed to continue to do this important work.

pros: Good company with positive community impact and outreach. Good benefits, laidback atmosphere most of the time.  People are committed to the programs. Allowed to work independently. Diversity.
cons: Inefficient systems, set in their ways. Things get overlooked, not much mobility. Sometimes things are slow and other times frantic, there needs to be a better way to manage time and resources.

pros: Center For Family Services does great work in our community every day. It is an organization that is constantly expanding so there are many opportunities for promotion/career expansion. As an employee for over 6 years, I feel valued and consistently challenged.
cons: Because of the rapid expansion of the organization some of the administrative departments are understaffed and it seems are often scrambling to keep up.

review_title: Great place to work but don't get sucked in.
pros: The exec team and staff truly care about their co-workers and the clients. Try to be flexible. Can be treated like a real person.
cons: They will over work you and make you feel like you don't really care if you try to set up boundaries between work and home life.

pros: Learning about and caring for the underprivileged
cons: Administration/CEO'S/AVP'S only care about their raises and bonus's via gov. grant monies. They only make improvements on the housing and give gifts to the children a few weeks before a State visit. Otherwise they say whatever we offer is better than what they came from.

review_title: work here at your own risk
pros: They hire a lot of people and they do give a good amount of holidays. Clients really need  the help.
cons: Salary is AWFUL and unfair. I can't believe I spent  two years at this place where they asked me to lie to licensing agencies and to referral agencies. They also said they couldn't give me a raise when other staff were given raises despite having lower evaluations and horrible work ethic and even though one staff person was caught in multiple unethical situations with the clients and instead of firing the employee, the administration moved this person to another location and paid this person MORE money -- the person actually got 2 paychecks!! I had tons of experience, a more education and great evaluations and yet the lazy and incompetent staff were continually getting raises and promotions. You get what you pay for and because they are so concerned about hiding and covering up for their bad employees, the don't pay their good ones a living wage. It was a circus.
